III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12206 Staff qualifications; volunteer,
Section contractors on central registry
Description
1

• (2) A staff member must be of responsible character and
suitable and able to meet the needs of children and families
served by the agency.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Foster Care worker threw away Youth A's medication while she
was hospitalized.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via telephone on August 7,
2025. She stated Youth A was admitted to Hurley Medical Center
on July 13, 2025, and was discharged on July 22, 2025. Upon
discharge there was an issue with Youth A’s medications. The
hospital e-scribed some medication to a pharmacy but not all
because they were under the impression Youth A had those from
previous placement. Complainant stated Foster Care Worker
admitted she didn’t have the other medications because she threw
them away. By this time, it was 8pm or 9pm. Complainant believes
the medication discarded was a psychotropic medication.
Foster Care worker (FCW) was interviewed via video
conference on August 12, 2025. FCW stated there were some
challenges with some of Youth A’s medications. The hospital
wrote prescriptions for medications. There were other medications
from Youth A’s previous placement that had been thrown away by
the foster parent. She believes Foster Parent threw away all the
medications except one but could not recall which one. Upon
discharge Youth A had the prescriptions she needed at that time
and FCW picked up the remaining prescriptions the following day.
Foster Care supervisor (FC supervisor) was interviewed via
video conference on August 12, 2025. He reported the hospital
only provided prescriptions for the medication they had changed.
FCW had to pick up the prescriptions Youth A had at the previous
foster placement. He isn’t aware of FCW or Foster Parent
discharging any medication. Youth A didn’t go without any
medication that was needed and FCW obtained the rest the
following day. He felt FCW did the best job she could during a
very difficult situation and maintained communication with the
hospital. He felt the hospital was taking out other frustrations on
FCW.
Documents reviewed:
• Youth A’s MISACWIS case file. July 22, 2025, and July 23,
2025 social work contacts indicate FCW went to 2 separate
pharmacies and picked up some of Youth A’s medication
prior to discharge and the rest the following morning.
2

Analysis The agency is found to be in compliance. Based on completed
interviews and review of Youth A’s MISACWIS case file there is
documentation FCW obtained Youth A’s prescription medication.
There is no reason to believe Youth A went without vital
medication during placement changes.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12320 Supervision
Section • (1) An agency shall ensure an appropriate level of care and
Description supervision for the foster child at all times consistent with a
child's age, level of functioning, and treatment plan.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency failed to pick up youth from hospital despite youth being
ready for discharge.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via telephone on August 7,
2025. Youth A was admitted on July 13, 2025. Complainant stated
she spoke with FCW on July 14, 2025, who reported Youth A
would not be returning to previous foster placement and FCW was
working on alternative placement. Youth A was a quick readmit,
meaning she had been there very recently and explained to FCW
this would be a short hospitalization, so the agency was aware.
Wednesday of that week there was the treatment team meeting,
and they would be able to provide a better idea of the discharge
date. FCW was called and participated in the treatment team
meeting and was told Youth A’s scheduled discharge was Friday,
July 18, 2025.
Complainant called FCW and let her know the hospital can keep
Youth A through the weekend and to plan for discharge on
Monday, July 21, 2025. FCW reported there still wasn’t a
placement secured. Complainant stated the agency needed to
pick her up at the discharge date. FCW reported she doesn’t work
on Mondays. The hospital agreed to update the discharge date to
Tuesday, July 22, 2025, to work with the agency. The hospital was
also doing some minor adjustments with Youth A’s medications
and could monitor.
Complainant stated on Friday July 18, 2025, she requested a
pickup plan from FCW since she reported not working on
Mondays. FCW agreed to pick Youth A up at noon on Tuesday,
July 22, 2025. On Tuesday, she spoke with FCW first thing in the
morning and FCW reported placement unit had not located a
placement. FCW inquired if the hospital would be willing to do a
single case agreement while they continue to search for
placement. The hospital stated that wasn’t appropriate and
3

declined. Complainant stated she and others from the hospital
repeatedly tried calling FCW and she would not answer. FCW
eventually picked up Youth A later in the evening around 7pm.
Foster Care worker (FCW) was interviewed via video
conference on August 12, 2025. She stated Youth A was placed
at Hurley from July 13, 2025, through July 22, 2025. She stated
this was the second time she had been placed there, and the
agency was aware they needed to locate a new foster placement
upon discharge as Foster Parent indicated Youth A was not able
to return to their home. FCW stated the agency put in a referral to
locate a new placement through the placement unit on June 30,
2025, or July 1, 2025, as soon as they were aware. Youth A’s
previous foster parent had put in her two week notice so the
agency knew Youth A couldn’t go back. The placement search
started right away. FCW stated she continued to update the
placement unit regarding Youth A’s discharge date.
Initially, Youth A was scheduled to be discharged on Friday, July
18, 2025, and then hospital placement changed it to the following
Monday and changed again to Tuesday, July 22, 2025. FCW
stated she and the agency continued to work on locating a
placement for Youth A all day on July 22, 2025, and the hospital
was adamant that she needed to be picked up and bring her to
their office if they didn’t have another option. FCW stated at that
point, they did not have placement or a safe discharge plan.
Hospital stated Youth A was sitting in the lobby. FCW stated she
informed the hospital that it might take a little longer since they
were still actively searching for a placement. She inquired how
late in the day would she be able to come and pick Youth A up
and was told it could be as late as 9pm that night as long as
someone picks her up. She reported to the hospital that it may
end up being an on call worker if it’s later in the evening.
FCW stated she was in frequent contact with the hospital social
worker. The hospital requested a pickup time prior to the
discharge date. FCW stated she told social worker to plan for
noon but will let her know on Tuesday morning and let her know if
it will be later than that because she didn’t know for sure what the
plan would be since a placement had not been located at that
time. She called social worker on Tuesday morning and informed
her the agency still does not have placement lined up and won’t
be able to pick her up at noon but asked when could be the latest
they picked her up. The hospital continued to press the agency,
but they didn’t have anywhere to put Youth A.
4

FCW stated she and her supervisor spoke with hospital staff
around 3pm and the hospital wasn’t happy. The hospital spoke
with the district manager who ended up securing a placement.
The placement located requested a higher rate and that took
additional time to work through. FCW stated she ended up picking
up Youth A around 6 or 6:30 that evening.
Foster Care supervisor (FC supervisor) was interviewed via
video conference on August 12, 2025. He stated he didn’t have
communication with hospital staff until it was closer to discharge.
FCW had been working with the regional placement unit for
approximately 10 days at that point. From the beginning the
placement unit was searching for a placement and FCW had
informed them of that.
FC supervisor stated hospital staff were noticeably frustrated and
reported to him that FCW had reported she would be picking
Youth A up and there are 3 other DHS kids in the emergency
room and Youth A was ready for discharge. They reported Youth
A was in their lobby with all her belongings. He felt that was
concerning because they had informed the hospital they were still
searching for placement, and it wasn’t confirmed they would be
picking her up. FC supervisor stated he reiterated to the hospital
that they did not have a safe discharge plan at that point and
inquired if it was possible if they would make a single case
agreement until a placement could be located. Shortly after, a
placement was located. FCW picked up Youth A sometime that
evening.
FC supervisor stated all along the discharge date was scheduled
for July 22, 2025, and Youth A was picked up on July 22, 2025.
He stated FCW reported she informed the hospital the original
pick up time of noon was not going to work since they hadn’t
secured a placement and asked how late she would be able to
pick Youth A up that day.
Documents reviewed:
• Youth A’s MISACWIS case file. Several social work
contacts on July 22, 2025, from FCW and FC supervisor to
Hurley indicate they did not have a safe discharge plan,
and they were continuing to look for placement.
Youth A’s placement history shows she was placed at
Hurley from June 30, 2025-July 8, 2025, and again July 13,
2025-July 22, 2025.
• July 1, 2025, email from FCW to placement unit providing
information on Youth A for placement search referral.
5

Analysis The agency is found in compliance. Based on completed
interviews and review of Youth A’s MISACWIS case file it was
clear the agency struggled to secure a safe placement upon
discharge from Hurley Medical Center. However, there is
documented effort of ongoing placement search. The agency was
able to secure placement in the early evening of July 22, 2025,
which is the originally scheduled discharge date.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.

sir_summary.summary: A special investigation examined allegations against a county child welfare agency regarding a youth's hospital discharge and medication. The first allegation, that a foster care worker threw away the youth's medication, was not substantiated; interviews and case file review showed the worker obtained the necessary prescriptions and the youth did not go without vital medication. The second allegation, that the agency failed to timely pick up the youth from the hospital, was also not substantiated; the investigation found the agency actively searched for a placement for over a week and ultimately secured one on the scheduled discharge date, though it occurred later in the evening. The report's conclusion that no substantial violations were found indicates the agency's actions, while challenging and delayed, did not rise to the level of a licensing rule violation.
